68563.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
This is the title of a specific sutta in the Saṃyutta Nikāya (SN 45.8). It belongs to the Maggasaṃyutta (Chapter on the Path). The sutta is called "Analysis" because it systematically breaks down and analyzes the Noble Eightfold Path. The contextual sentence shows it is a text title followed by its number within the chapter.

40556.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence shows this is a sutta title within the Khandhasaṃyutta of the Saṃyutta Nikāya (specifically SN22.44). It is a compound of 'paṭipadā' (path) and 'sutta' (discourse).

13248.meaning_1: The Sutta on Nutriment (the fourth of the seven Sets of Factors of Enlightenment, dealing with the four nutriments)
13248.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The Āhārasutta is the fourth set in the Bojjhaṅgasaṃyutta (SN 46), dealing with the four nutriments (āhāra) as factors of enlightenment.

33399.meaning_1: second discourse on samaṇas and brāhmaṇas
33399.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence (SN12.30) identifies this as the second sutta in the Nidānasaṃyutta, specifically dealing with samaṇas and brāhmaṇas. The number 2 in the headword indicates it is the second discourse in this series.

915.meaning_1: The Sutta of the Naked Ascetic Kassapa (first of two)
915.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
Contextual sentence shows it is the title of a sutta in the Saṃyutta Nikāya, specifically the first sutta in the Nidāna Saṃyutta (SN12.17).

46497.meaning_1: wanting to ask; wishing to enquire
46497.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence shows the phrase "pucchitukāmā" (nom. pl. masc.) used with the verb "atthi" (implied), meaning "we have a wish to ask". The English translation "I don’t want to ask much" is a free translation; the literal meaning is "not greatly wanting to ask" (na kho pana mayaṃ bahudeva pucchitukāmā). The compound is a bahubbīhi (relative) compound where the infinitive + kāma functions as an adjective modifying the subject.
46497.sutta_1: “na kho pana mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ bahudeva pucchitukāmā”ti.

70267.meaning_1: suffering a feeling; afflicted by pain
70267.sutta_1: ‘añño karoti añño paṭisaṃvedayatī’ti kho, kassapa, vedanābhitunnassa sato ‘paraṅkataṃ dukkhan’ti iti vadaṃ ucchedaṃ etaṃ pareti.
70267.example_1: Suppose that he who does the deed is one, and he who experiences the result is another. Then for one stricken by feeling, suffering is made by another. In speaking like this, one implies this is annihilated.

44308.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The word appears in the context of monastic probation (parivāsa). In SN12.17, it describes a person who has completed the required probation period (parivuṭṭhaparivāsaṃ) and is then eligible for ordination. The spelling variant 'parivutthaparivāsa' (id 44311) is noted as a related headword, but this entry uses the spelling from the original context sentence.
44308.example_1: yo kho, kassapa, aññatitthiyapubbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhati pabbajjaṃ, ākaṅkhati upasampadaṃ, so cattāro māse parivasati. catunnaṃ māsānaṃ accayena [accayena parivuṭṭhaparivāsaṃ] (parivutthaparivāsaṃ) āraddhacittā bhikkhū [bhikkhū ākaṅkhamānā] pabbājenti upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya. api ca mayā puggalavemattatā viditāti.

30716.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
Timbaruka is the name of a brahmin. The sutta discusses his question about the world being eternal or not, and the Buddha's response regarding the causes of confusion and suffering.

30715.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
Personal name of a wanderer (paribbājako) who approaches the Buddha in the Saṃyutta Nikāya. The name appears to be a derivative of the word "timbaru," possibly relating to a tree or fruit, similar to other personal names derived from natural elements.
30715.sutta_1: atha kho timbaruko paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
30715.example_1: Then the wanderer Timbaruka went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

48289.meaning_1: Sutta on the Fool and the Wise
48289.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence SN12.19 shows this is the title of a sutta in the Nidānasaṃyutta of the Saṃyutta Nikāya. The word is a compound meaning "The Sutta of the Fool and the Wise." The "2" in the lemma_1 likely distinguishes it from other suttas with similar titles or numbering variants.

53829.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the provided context, the word appears in the derivative form "adhippayāso" which is analyzed as adhi + pa + yasu + ṇa + sī. This is a grammatical analysis of a compound formation where √yas is the root meaning "strive, struggle". The lemma itself is a grammatical root (kita) ending in -u, classified as masculine.
53829.example_1: tatra, bhikkhave, ko viseso ko adhippayāso [adhippāyo, adhippāyaso adhi + pa + yasu + ṇa + sī = adhippayāso] kiṃ nānākaraṇaṃ paṇḍitassa bālenāti? bhagavaṃmūlakā no, bhante, dhammā, bhagavaṃnettikā, bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā.

21284.sutta_1: tasmā bālo kāyassa bhedā kāyūpago hoti,
21284.example_1: Therefore, when their body breaks up, the fool is reborn in another body.

151.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence shows this adjective used as an epithet for one who has escaped the cycle of rebirth (jātiyā jarāmaraṇena), confirming the meaning "not passing on to another body" or "not subject to rebirth."
151.sutta_1: so akāyūpago samāno parimuccati jātiyā jarāmaraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi.
151.example_1: Not passing on to another body, they’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

39396.meaning_1: sutta on conditions; discourse on causality
39396.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the context SN12.20, 'paccayasuttaṃ' refers to a specific discourse within the Nidānasaṃyutta (Connected Discourses on Causation) of the Saṃyutta Nikāya, dealing with the twelve links of dependent origination (paticcasamuppāda).

32033.meaning_1: the group of the ten powers
32033.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
This is the title of a chapter (vagga) in the Saṃyutta Nikāya. The contextual sentence indicates it is the third vagga. The meaning refers to the ten powers (dasabala) of a Buddha, which is a standard set of attributes.

32032.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence SN 12.21 (nidānasaṃyuttaṃ, dasabalasuttaṃ) refers to a sutta within the Nidānasaṃyutta (Connected Discourses on Causation), which is part of the Saṃyutta Nikāya. The sutta likely discusses the Tathāgata's ten powers of knowledge.

33258.meaning_1: second discourse on the ten powers
33258.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The word appears as the title of a sutta in the Nidānasaṃyutta (SN 12.22). It refers to the second sutta in a series dealing with the ten powers (dasabala), likely referring to the ten powers of a Tathāgata. The structure is a kammadhāraya compound where 'dutiyā' (second) qualifies the compound 'dasabalasutta' (discourse on the ten powers).

46058.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the context of SN12.22, the compound is part of a larger string enumerating requisites (cīvara-piṇḍapātasenāsana-gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ). The meaning is the standard one of 'alms-food and accommodation'.
46058.example_1: evaṃ no ayaṃ amhākaṃ pabbajjā avañjhā bhavissati saphalā saudrayā. yesañca [yesaṃ, yesaṃ hi] mayaṃ paribhuñjāma cīvara-piṇḍapātasenāsana-gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ tesaṃ te kārā amhesu mahapphalā bhavissanti mahānisaṃsāti, evañhi vo, bhikkhave, sikkhitabbaṃ. attatthaṃ vā hi, bhikkhave, sampassamānena alameva appamādena sampādetuṃ, paratthaṃ vā hi, bhikkhave, sampassamānena alameva appamādena sampādetuṃ, ubhayatthaṃ vā hi, bhikkhave, sampassamānena alameva appamādena sampādetunti.

15801.meaning_1: conditional sutta; sutta on the conditions for something
15801.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence SN12.23, the word appears as the title of a sutta within the Nidānasaṃyutta. It refers to a sutta that explains the conditional relationships (paccaya) between phenomena, likely detailing how one thing arises in dependence on another (e.g., ignorance leads to volitional formations, etc.). The prefix upani- here means "towards, near to," indicating a sutta that approaches or explains the conditions for existence. It is a neuter compound.

56822.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence shows this word used as a neuter singular accusative/adjective (saṅkhārūpanisaṃ) modifying viññāṇaṃ, within the chain of dependent origination where volitional formations are the conditioning factor for consciousness. It is a compound of saṅkhāra (volitional formations) + upanisa (condition, basis).
56822.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
56822.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”

67759.meaning_2: with consciousness as vital condition; consciousness-dependent
67759.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
Appears in the dependent origination chain (paṭiccasamuppāda) as a link where consciousness conditions name-and-form. It functions as a descriptive adjective indicating that consciousness is the supporting condition (upanisā) for the subsequent link.
67759.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
67759.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”

36470.meaning_1: with name and form as pre-condition
36470.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
This compound describes the dependent relationship where the six sense bases (saḷāyatana) have name and form (nāmarūpa) as their vital condition or pre-condition, forming part of the causal chain of dependent origination (paṭiccasamuppāda) as shown in the contextual sentence from SN12.23.
36470.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
36470.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”

61524.meaning_1: with six sense fields as pre-condition
61524.meaning_2: having the six sense fields as its indispensable condition
61524.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the context of the Paṭiccasamuppāda chain (SN12.23), 'saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso' means 'contact is the vital condition for the six sense fields' (or more colloquially, 'contact has the six sense fields as its condition'). This follows the pattern where the genitive plural suffix 'naṃ' is often used in compounds (saḷāyatanānaṃ > saḷāyatana), similar to other entries in the list like 'saḷāyatananirodha'.
61524.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
61524.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”

47681.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence presents the word in the feminine nominative singular form (phassūpanisā), defining feeling (vedanā) as being conditioned by contact (phassa). This aligns with the doctrinal concept of dependent origination, where contact is a necessary condition for the arising of feeling.
47681.example_1: Contact is the vital condition for feeling.

70294.meaning_2: having feeling as a vital condition
70294.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the context of dependent origination (paṭiccasamuppāda), this term describes how craving (taṇhā) arises dependent on feeling (vedanā). The English translation "with feeling as pre-condition" accurately reflects the conditional relationship in the chain: "phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā". The term follows the pattern seen in other chain links like avijjūpanisa and taṇhūpanisa.
70294.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
70294.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”

29424.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence, this word describes "upādāna" (clinging) as being dependent on "taṇhā" (craving), forming a link in the twelve-fold chain of dependent origination (paṭiccasamuppāda). The meaning is "having craving as its immediate condition/upanisā".
29424.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
29424.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”

16346.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The word appears in the compound chain of dependent origination (paṭiccasamuppāda) as a descriptive term for bhava (existence) being conditioned by upādāna (clinging). It functions adjectivally, describing a state that has grasping as its essential condition or indispensable prerequisite.
16346.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
16346.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”

49630.meaning_1: with being as pre-condition; having being as vital condition
49630.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the context of Dependent Origination (paṭiccasamuppāda), this adjective describes a link where a prior state of existence is the direct condition for the next link (jāti). It functions as a technical term in the chain: "bhavūpanisā jāti" (birth is conditioned by becoming).
49630.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
49630.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”

28292.meaning_2: having birth as its condition; originating from birth
28292.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the context of paṭiccasamuppāda, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ means "birth is the condition for suffering," specifically indicating that birth is the dependent origin of suffering. The word appears as a compound adjective modifying dukkhaṃ.
28292.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
28292.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”

33016.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence, this is used as an adjective describing dukkha as being the vital condition (upanisā) for saddhā (faith). It functions in a chain of dependent origination, showing suffering as the basis for the arising of faith.
33016.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
33016.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”

58111.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence (sn12.23:8.1) presents a chain of conditions where each element is the "vital condition" (upanisa) for the next. Here, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ means "joy which has faith as its vital condition." The word is formed from saddhā (faith) and upanisā (vital condition/requisite), with the final -ā of saddhā becoming -ū- through vowel sandhi before the u of upanisā. The meaning is similar to its counterpart in the chain, dukkhūpanisā saddhā (faith has suffering as its vital condition), showing a reciprocal relationship in the cycle of dependent origination.
58111.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
58111.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”

45696.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the context of the Dependent Origination chain (SN 12.23), it appears as pāmojjūpanisā pīti, meaning "joy has gladness as its condition" or "joy is dependent on gladness." It functions in a series of compound adjectives describing the conditional relationships in the chain.
45696.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
45696.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”

46415.meaning_2: having delight as a vital condition
46415.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence (SN12.23), pītūpanisā passaddhi is the sixth link in the positive dependent origination series (pavattappaṭiccasamuppāda). It describes passaddhi (tranquility) as being conditioned by pīti (delight/rapture). This is a tatiyā tappurisa (instrumental/conditional) compound, where pīti is the agent or condition that brings about passaddhi.
46415.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
46415.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”

44752.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
44752.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”

63599.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The compound is a kammadhāraya where "sukha" is the qualifier. In the context (SN12.23), it is part of the chain of dependent origination: "sukhūpaniso samādhi" means "concentration, for which ease is a condition". The meaning is more specific than just "with ease"; it indicates ease as a direct, vital condition (upanisā) for the next link in the chain.
63599.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
63599.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”

59687.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the context of the dependent origination chain (paṭiccasamuppāda), this term describes a condition where mental composure (samādhi) is a proximate cause (upanisā) for the arising of subsequent phenomena, here specifically for the knowledge of things as they are (yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ).
59687.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
59687.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”

53660.meaning_1: with understanding and insight into things as they really are as pre-condition
53660.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence shows this word as an adjective modifying the condition (upanisa) for nibbidā (disenchantment). It is part of the dependent origination chain where yathābhūtañāṇadassana (knowledge and seeing things as they are) becomes the pre-condition for disenchantment.
53660.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
53660.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”

37675.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
Formed from nibbidā (disenchantment) + upanisā (vital condition). The compound exhibits a phonetic change (ā + u > ū) typical in Pāḷi sandhi. It is the compound form describing something that has dis-enchantment as its underlying condition or prerequisite.
37675.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
37675.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”

68891.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
Used in the dependent origination sequence (SN 12.23) as a link in the chain, meaning dispassion (virāga) is the essential condition (upanisa) for liberation (vimutti).
68891.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
68891.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”

22707.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence from SN12.23 describes water flowing from a mountain, filling 'kusobbhe' (ravines/gullies), which then fill 'mahāsobbhe' (large ravines/gullies). The variant spellings (kusubbha, kusobha) are noted in the commentary. The meaning 'ravine, gully' fits the context of water collecting in topographical depressions.
22707.example_1: seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, uparipabbate thullaphusitake deve vassante taṃ udakaṃ yathāninnaṃ pavattamānaṃ pabbatakandarapadarasākhā paripūreti. pabbatakandarapadarasākhāparipūrā kusobbhe [kussubbhe, kusubbhe ṇvādi 129 suttaṃ oloketabbaṃ] paripūrenti. kusobbhā paripūrā mahāsobbhe paripūrenti.

29185.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence, the word is part of a gloss on a textual variant for "kusobbhe" (small streams), referenced as "ṇvādi 129 suttaṃ oloketabbaṃ" (look at sutta 129 of the ṇvādi chapter). The ṇvādi is a chapter in the Moggallānabyākaraṇa dealing with taddhita (derivational) suffixes that begin with ṇ (like ṇaka, ṇanīya, etc.).
29185.example_1: seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, uparipabbate thullaphusitake deve vassante taṃ udakaṃ yathāninnaṃ pavattamānaṃ pabbatakandarapadarasākhā paripūreti. pabbatakandarapadarasākhāparipūrā kusobbhe [kussubbhe, kusubbhe ṇvādi 129 suttaṃ oloketabbaṃ] paripūrenti. kusobbhā paripūrā mahāsobbhe paripūrenti.

1528.meaning_1: sutta of the Saṃyutta Nikāya concerning other sectarians
1528.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
This is the title of a sutta in the Saṃyutta Nikāya (SN 12.24). The contextual sentence shows the sutta is part of the Nidānasaṃyutta. The compound refers to a discourse involving other sectarians (titthiyas).

20361.meaning_1: (proponent of) doctrine of causality; who hold the view that actions have consequences
20361.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence uses kammavādā as the nominative plural masculine, referring to ascetics and brahmins who teach the efficacy of actions. The meaning is clarified by the subsequent statement about suffering being made by oneself, which is a specific instance of the doctrine that actions have consequences.
20361.sutta_1: “santāvuso sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṃ dukkhaṃ paññapenti.
20361.example_1: “Reverend Sāriputta, there are ascetics and brahmins who teach the efficacy of deeds. Some of them declare that suffering is made by oneself.

28250.meaning_1: produced by conception; generated by birth
28250.sutta_1: ‘jarāmaraṇaṃ kho, āvuso, jātinidānaṃ jātisamudayaṃ jātijātikaṃ jātipabhavan’ti.
28250.example_1: ‘Reverends, rebirth is the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of old age and death.’

49544.sutta_1: ‘jāti kho, āvuso, bhavanidānā bhavasamudayā bhavajātikā bhavappabhavā’ti.
49544.example_1: ‘Continued existence is the source of rebirth.’

49590.meaning_1: with being as source; originating from existence
49590.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the context of sn12.24, the phrase 'bhavanidānā bhavasamudayā' describes the condition of 'jāti' (rebirth) as being rooted in and arising from 'bhava' (continued existence). The word functions as an adjective describing the origin of rebirth.
49590.sutta_1: ‘jāti kho, āvuso, bhavanidānā bhavasamudayā bhavajātikā bhavappabhavā’ti.
49590.example_1: ‘Continued existence is the source of rebirth.’

49566.meaning_1: produced by being; generated by existence
49566.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the context of sn12.24:19.4, it is part of the phrase "bhavappabhavā" which qualifies jāti (rebirth) as being "born from existence" or "having existence as its origin." This aligns with the meaning "produced by being."
49566.sutta_1: ‘jāti kho, āvuso, bhavanidānā bhavasamudayā bhavajātikā bhavappabhavā’ti.
49566.example_1: ‘Continued existence is the source of rebirth.’

16325.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence (sn12.24:20.4) uses 'upādānanidāno' in the nominative masculine singular, agreeing with 'bhavo' (existence). The compound is a descriptive adjective meaning 'having grasping as its source.' It is part of a series of descriptions for 'bhavo,' where 'upādānanidāno' is synonymous with 'upādānasamudayo' (grasping as origin/arising).
16325.sutta_1: ‘bhavo kho, āvuso, upādānanidāno upādānasamudayo upādānajātiko upādānappabhavo’ti.
16325.example_1: ‘Grasping is the source of continued existence.’

16332.meaning_1: produced by clinging; generated by grasping
16332.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence ('upādānappabhavo’ti) shows the word in the nominative singular masculine form (upādānappabhavo), derived from the compound 'upādāna + pabhava' meaning 'produced by clinging.' It functions adjectivally, describing the nature of bhavo (existence/being) as arising from upādāna (clinging/grasping).
16332.sutta_1: ‘bhavo kho, āvuso, upādānanidāno upādānasamudayo upādānajātiko upādānappabhavo’ti.
16332.example_1: ‘Grasping is the source of continued existence.’

61514.meaning_1: produced by the six sense fields
61514.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence at sn12.24:21.8 lists saḷāyatanappabhava as the final item in a series describing the origin of contact (phasso), alongside saḷāyatananidāna (source), saḷāyatanasamudayo (origin), and saḷāyatanajātiko (birthplace). It functions attributively, modifying phasso implicitly, indicating that contact arises from or is produced by the six sense fields.
61514.sutta_1: ‘phasso kho, āvuso, saḷāyatananidāno saḷāyatanasamudayo saḷāyatanajātiko saḷāyatanappabhavo’ti.
61514.example_1: ‘The six sense fields are the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of contact.’

50220.meaning_1: Sutta about the ground; Earth Sutta
50220.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The word appears in the context of SN12.25, which is part of the Nidānasaṃyutta. The sutta likely discusses the concept of "ground" or "base" (bhūmi) in relation to dependent origination or the arising of phenomena. The related headwords show compounds starting with "akaṭa" (not done), but "bhūmijasutta" is a positive compound referring to a sutta about the earth or ground.

68754.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
This adjective describes something that has liberation (vimutti) as its immediate condition or proximate cause (upanisa). In the contextual sentence (SN 12.23), it completes the dependent origination chain, stating that freedom (vimutti) is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending (khaye ñāṇa). It mirrors other compounds in the passage like 'avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā'.
68754.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
68754.example_1: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”
